sanskrit:
हतो वा प्राप्स्यसि स्वर्गं जित्वा वा भोक्ष्यसे महीम् |
तस्मादुत्तिष्ठ कौन्तेय युद्धाय कृतनिश्चयः ||३७||
transliteration:
hato vā prāpsyasi svargaṁ jitvā vā bhokṣyase mahīm |
tasmād uttiṣṭha kaunteya yuddhāya kṛta-niścayaḥ ||37||
translation: If you are slain, you will attain heaven; if you are victorious, you will enjoy the earth. Therefore, arise, O son of Kunti, resolved to fight.
commentary:
In this verse, Krishna presents a compelling argument based on the worldly perspective of duty and consequences. He offers Arjuna a win-win proposition: either death in battle leads to heavenly rewards (svarga), or victory brings earthly sovereignty and enjoyment. This is a transitional verse where Krishna shifts from the philosophical discourse on the immortality of the soul to practical considerations that would appeal to a warrior's sense of duty and honor.

Krishna addresses Arjuna as 'Kaunteya' (son of Kunti), reminding him of his noble lineage and the dharmic obligations that come with it. The verse emphasizes that regardless of the outcome, Arjuna has nothing to lose by performing his prescribed duty as a warrior. Death in righteous battle guarantees spiritual elevation, while victory ensures worldly prosperity and the fulfillment of his role as a protector of dharma.

This verse is significant in the overall structure of the Gita as it bridges the metaphysical teachings about the eternal nature of the soul with the practical ethics of karma yoga. Krishna is preparing Arjuna to understand that action performed as duty, without attachment to results, is the path of the wise. The exhortation to arise with firm resolve (kṛta-niścayaḥ) foreshadows the later teachings on equanimity and steadfastness in action.
speaker: Krishna
